know his name and address"—he said "I know neither"—I said "Do you buy goods without getting a bill or receipt?"—he said "No, no doubt I have one somewhere"—he searched, and produced a bill from which the printed head had been torn off, and the writing was so obscure that it could not be deciphered whether it was wax or not—I said that he had made a mistake in giving me that—I still pressed him for the name and address—he said he would ask the man when he called again—on 30th April I called again, leaving Thursday between—I said to Howe "I have called again about that wax, and hope you are in a position to give me the address of the person of whom you bought it"—he said "Yes," and he gave me a receipt in the name of Haywood on one of his own bill-heads—I said "This is no address"—he said "The seller declines to give his address"—I then produced some samples I received from Mr. Gadsden, and said "I am informed you have offered wax to this sample, for sale to the amount of 2 cwt."—he said "I have not'—he was asked that question several times, and repeated the same answer—I can't say whether the samples I showed him were my manu
facture, because they Were so small—Croome mentioned Castle's name amongst several others, as persons from whom he might have bought the wax—he said "No," to 'every name that was mentioned, including Castle—Ralph's name was not mentioned—on Tuesday, 3rd June", my manager, ‘Mr. Walker, brought Witham to me—I made no inducement to Witham, but I had offered a reward by placards—I did not promise not to prosecute him.

MR. LYON. Q. Did you make him any promise in words? A. No—I told him any information he gave me, would not be forgotten—I dis
tinctly suggested to him that he should be a witness—(MR. LYON contended that Witham's statement under these circumstances was inadmissible, as a hope of reward was held out id him. THE COURT considered that the evidence could not be excluded, as Without was not then under charge, and no promise or threat was made to him.)

MR. STRAIGHT. Q. What did Witham say? A. He said "I come to you consequent on feeling regret that so many innocent men should be thrown out of employ"—I had discharged some of my men—I had closed one department of the premises at Upper Marsh—he said • I have offered wax by Castle's instructions to three persons, one is Mr. Hale, of Lambeth Road, and Mr. Steane, of Lambeth Walk, and to an oilman in Union Street, whose name I have forgotten, but I did not succeed in selling any"—he also said "It is within my knowledge that this robbery has gone on for two years and a half, and to the extent of about 3 cwt. a week on an average"—I said "Will you give me any further information?—he said "I must have time to consider of it"—I think he said he wanted twenty-four hours, on some hours—he left, promising to see me at the railway station next morning—he did not see me, because I gave instructions for his apprehen
sion—I have a traveller in my employ named Soames, who in April showed me some wax he had purchased for me—I examined it and identified it as my manufacture—it was white wax finished, and was worth 2s. 8d.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. I am not prepared to prove that Howe did not buy any large quantities of wax—the wax sold by Howe at 1s. 8d. was sold at a fair price—there are three wax bleachers in the metropolis—I employ the same method as they do, and a method of my own in addition, that leaves a small grain oh the surface which, to a practical eye, is unmig
taxable;

but Howe possessed only yellow wax and no bleached wax, to my knowledge—I identify the wax Howe had by its peculiar appearance, and it also fitted into my tins—I swear to my own manufacture; it is my positive and absolute oath—the samples are about as big as walnuts; they are for the purpose of tradesmen judging of the quality—I declined to identify these samples on account of their smallness—samples are generally double that size, you seldom see a piece so small as this—Mr. Gadsden gave this to me—Howe had no idea that Croome was a detective till I said so—Hove was not open in his answers, quite the reverse—he represented the invoice of some oil as the invoice of wax—he said that the man had been there on Thursday and given the name of Haywood, and refused his address—he keeps am oil and colour shop, not a marine store dealer's—I should not have sold this wax in this state; it is competent to anybody to buy, but we don't sell goods in am unfinished state—I do not say that nobody ought to have bought it—I have always denied that—James King has bought a good deal, and Jewell also—John Edwards purchased a large quantity of my wax from King—the is not present—80 lbs. of my wax was purchased by Mr. Sundell, but it was not found there; he had none left—Sundell and Edwards purchased pieces in a finished state—I told Howe that unless he told me how he came in possession of my property I must find out for myself—he knew at that time that Croome was a detective—MESSRS. Johnson are a highly respectable firm—I buy wax largely for the purpose of making up, and I may purchase wax in the market—I very seldom buy wax of my own unfinished—Rumble is my witness—he has been paid money by me in the course of this case—I can't tell you how much—none of it has passed through my hands—he is a painter—I heard it stated at the Police Court that he is a convicted thief—I have given Sergeant Croome money to be expended amongst the witnesses for their travelling expenses to the different Mice Courts—I believe any direct money paid has been paid by our foreman, Thomas Brock well—I saw no wax in Howe's shop—I have heard that it was in the window, exposed for sale, and sold over the counter.

Re-examined. I heard Rumble examined at the Police Court, and then knew for the first time that he had been convicted, and that after his con
viction he was taken back—I found that Gregory, Penny & Co. had an order from King for wax, but it had not been delivered—the receipt that Howe showed me, with the corner torn off, was for paraffin oil—I did not notice that on the first occasion, because I could not read it—Haywood's receipt represented 28 lbs. of wax—what I received from Addis was a sample of the 2 cwt. he had been asked to sell.

THOMAS BROCKWELL . I am Mr. Field's foreman, at Tipper Marsh, where the wax bleaching goes on—Ralph was a labourer there—I remember a package being brought from the City premises—I found in it three blocks of yellow wax, similar to those I had manufactured for Clark & Sons in January—I identified a portion of it as sample blocks of that manufacture the remainder of it consisted of oblong blocks of yellow wax in pieces, which I also identify as Messrs. Field's manufacture—I went to King's premises, and saw two blocks of semi-refined wax there, which I identified as Messrs. Field's—it was wax which is not sold by itself, except for the purpose of being mixed with other wax—I also saw, in King's bedroom, about 2 cwt. of refined yellow wax, which I identify as our manufacture—I then went to the landing, and saw four boxes of refined yellow wax, bleached

and finished, in condition for sale, which I identified as Mr. Fields manu
facture—I also found a bag there with two sorts of wax in it, mixed up in pieces—that was our manufacture also—I sent to Messrs. Johnson & Sons' some wax of Mr. Field's manufacture, and noticed that two blocks of it were not finished for sale—as to the second lot supplied to Clark, 10 tons of it were made in earthenware vessels—I identify it by the shape of the vessels in which it is made—the former parcel was made in tin vessels—Rumble was ultimately brought to me—his name was mentioned, and I remember his coming to the premises about 24th or 25th April—nine men were brought out altogether, and Ralph amongst them—Humble pointed out Ralph the moment he saw him—on 30th May I went to Messrs. Middleton's premises in St. George's-in-the-East, and was shown some wax there—I had with me a portion of wax that Croome gave me, which had been purchased at Howe's—part of what I saw at Middleton's was in an unfinished state—a portion of that which Croome gave me was unfinished, and both were part and parcel of the same material.

Cross-examined by MR. W. SLEIGH. I saw some wax in pieces, in a bag, at King's; some of them were as large as the palm of your hand, some larger, and some smaller—I can't say whose manufacture this piece produced is, because it is in such a dirty condition—I don't know that I could recognise it if it was clean, but if it was white wax, and a little larger, I could; if the pieces were clean, it is very likely I might pick out a great portion of them—I think I could recognise this piece without any difficulty, because no one manufactures it in the same way as we do—I know it by the beautiful was in which it is got up; our wax is, I believe, got up better than anyone else's—I don't think it is more difficult to identify white wax than yellow, if you give me a piece of the proper size.

Cross-examined by MR. M. WILLIAMS. Middleton's looked like an oil-shop when I was there—I should think they are respectable—the wax I saw brought there was about 50 lbs.; one block was in an unfinished state
Johnson & Co. are tallow chandlers, I think—the blocks they brought were not all unfinished; my two were—I don't know Mr. Williams, of the Minories—I don't know how much money altogether has been given to witnesses in this case—I have paid them about 5s. a day, for their loss of time in attending at the Police Court, but only to four or five, the others were too respectable—I paid Mrs. Denman, Mrs. Booth, and Rumble; that is about all—I can't say how much I gave Mrs. Dennis; I have kept no account—I paid the money out of my own pocket first—I paid her 2l., or it may have been a trifle more—it was at the rate of 5s. a day, and sometimes a little more—the firm have repaid me, but I can't tell you off hand what I charged them for Mrs. Dennis—I drawed it from Mr. Oliver, the cashier—I have only paid Mrs. Booth 10s.; and I daresay Rumble has had the same as Mrs. Dennis, two sovereigns—I have seen Mrs. Frances—I have not paid her a penny—I don't know of anyone else distributing the money of the firm—MRS. Simons has had about 15s. from me, that was for her and her son; Mrs. Cook was all in the same lot; that includes the lot—I lumped them all together—I know of several men going into Horsemonger Land Gaol who have been in our employment, and are out of employment through this unfortunate job—I don't know that they went to ask any of the prisoners to give evidence—I don't know of Baker going into Horsemonger Lane Gaol—I never saw him there—I did not wait outside—I know he started to
go, he did not go by my authority—he asked me if he should, and I said he must take the responsibility on himself—I don't think he is here.

Re-examined. Baker was in Mr. Field's employment in the department which is closed—whatever he did or said at Horsemonger Lane Gaol he had no authority whatever from me for—Dennis, Cook, Rumble, and Simons are all witnesses here—Mrs. Cook is Dennis's mother—whatever money I paid applied to the whole family—I paid them nothing except for attend
ance at the Police Court—Dennis only worked for the two Castles, according to her evidence, and Rumble also—Mrs. Simons resides in the neighbour
hood—I know nothing about giving Mrs. Frances 10s. for a new bonnet—I did not give her money for her mashed window after she gave her evidence—her window was smashed—when I used the expression "pieces," that applies to the 50 lbs. of wax in the bag—they offered me a better oppor
tunity of judging than the pieces I have seen to-day.
J. K. FIELD (re-called).

Cross-examined by MR. MONTAGU WILLIAMS. King was not a customer of mine at Lambeth Marsh—he was a customer of Ogilvie & Co., whose partner I am—he was not a customer for wax, but for candles and night-lights—he produced the receipts from Jewell—he paid 15d., 18d., and 20d. a pound—King occupies a good position—Johnson & Co. are unimpeachable; they bought some of this wax in an unsaleable state—the Edwards's are perfectly respectable; they are customers of mine for wax—Williams is undoubtedly a respectable man—he did not buy some of the wax—Addis if in William's employ, but Williams had nothing to do with the wax—the Middletons are highly respectable—they had not dealt with me before—the wax was in a state in which we do not sell it; it was in a state in which I would not send it out—when I first went to Jewell's, I told him it would be the worse for him if he did not tell me of whom he bought the wax, and he told me he got all of it from the Castles—I have endeavoured to find Jewell, but have not been successful—George Castle's is a private house; we did not search it or his mother's house—Mrs. Castle offered to allow us to search.

Re-examined. I made inquiries of Edwards, Johnson, & Co. and Middle
ton, and they told me satisfactorily how they obtained the wax.

CHARLES COLLYER BINGHAM . I am the Citv manager of Messrs. Field's establishment—he trades as Cowan & Co.—I don't know King's premises—I know him as an occasional customer—he came and asked if I would pur
chase some wax, and I sold him in return some night-lights—when I re
ceived the wax I sent it to the other establishment at Lambeth—on another day King brought me a bag with some broken pieces of wax, which is lying at Moorgate Street—Mr. Field saw the bag.

MR. SLEIGH to BROOKWILL. Q. Did you say at the Police Court?"J believe Messrs. Johnson & Co. must have purchased the wax through igno
rance; a good judge might be mistaken. A. I did, but not respecting those persons.

JOHN KING . I am an oil and oolourman, of 153, Union Street, Borough—I sell to Messrs. Cowan & Co., to Johnson & Co., and Gregory's—I sold (Gregory's 2 cwt. of white wax and about 3 cwt. of yellow; to Edwards, the doll maker, 4 or 6 cwt., and to Johnson about 2 cwt—when Mr. Field called on me I had 2 cwt. of yellow wax in my possession, and some white wax besides; about 17 cwt. altogether—I got that from Jewell, the marine store dealer of the New Cut—he began to come to me about July, 1872, and continued till about a fortnight before Mr. Field came to me—he

brought it in a cart sometimes, and sometimes in a barrow—and up to November last, George Castle used to be with him in the cart, but he did not come in—Jewell came alone after that—I don't know Howe—I always gave 1s. for the yellow and 1s. 8d. for the white—I have the invoice here, and I think one shows that I gave a little more for the white—the yellow was as if it had been turned out of a basin, and the white was sometimes in blocks and sometimes in broken pieces—the white was gene
rally whole, but there may have been a broken piece now and then—I have not seen Jewell since this inquiry.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. I don't understand much about the wax trade—I don't think I understand enough to make a bargain—I don't know that Mr. Field has sworn that the wax found at my premises was worth over 2s. a pound—I kept the whole of it in my shop—I swear that—I small portion of it was found in my bedroom, which I removed in conse
quence of an alteration on my premises—that was only about 2 cwt.—I had in stock at that time, I think, 2 cwt., and likewise 2 cwt. of white in the warehouse—all the rest was in the bedroom—the transactions began before November, 1872—I have been to Jewell's shop—he deals in rags and bones, and metal—I sold that wax to Gregory's at 2s. 1d. a pound—I paid 1s. 6d. for it—he had an invoice either from me or my son, with my name and address on it—I asked Jewell where he got the wax—I thought it a funny thing that a rag and bone dealer should be dealing in wax—he said he had it from a firm who had an account with a wax house—that was sufficient information for me, and I bought with confidence.

Cross-examined by MR. M. WILLIAMS. I thought I was giving a fair price for it—it is on my invoice—I am in a large way of business—I do about 9,000l. a year—I was satisfied with Jewell's representation—I had known him sometime, and knew his father-in-law, Mr. Davis, of London Road—I did not think it extraordinary that he should be dealing in wax—I deal in wax—I did not know that it was in an unfinished state when I bought it.

Re-examined. Seventeen hundredweight in five or six months is not 8 large dealing for an oil and colour man—I should be satisfied to buy double the quantity—I hear that Jewell has got out of the way—I only know it from hearsay; I have not taken any trouble to inquire.
GEORGE JOHNSON . I am a candle-maker, of 175, Bishopsgate Street Without—I received about half a dozen blocks of yellow wax from Mr. King in exchange for candles.

Cross-examined by MR. M. WILLIAMS. The bargain was at 1s. 9d. per lb., but it was not paid for—I believe it to be a fair price—I chiefly trade in tallow, but I buy wax—I do not know much about it, or whether it was in an unfinished state.
JOHN EDWARDS . I am a wax-doll manufacturer, of Waterloo Road—I bought wax of Mr. King, and showed a sample of it to Mr. Field.
Cross-examined by MR. M. WILLIAMS. I paid 1s. 8d. or 1s. 10d. per lb. for it, and I gave a fair price for it.
Re-examined. I have bought wax from Mr. Field, and have given him more, but not for the same sort of wax.

JOHN WILLIAM RUMBLE . I am a painter—I know George Castle and Jewell—was in Mrs. Castle's service several times, on and off, to Christmas last—she and George Castle were together at that time—they kept a rag and metal shop—George Castle managed it chiefly, but his mother attended

to the shop—I have seen wax there a great many times—the last time was in September—the yellow wax was in the shape of a basin, and the white in cakes about the size of this book, but broken—I have seen Ralph; bring it in a truck or barrow, and under his coat, more than once—George Castle received it from him, and I have seen him put it into the scale, and his mother sent out the money to Ralph—I used to go out in a cart with Ralph on a Saturday, and I have put yellow and white wax into the cart at his direc
tion—we went with it first to Suffolk Street, Whitechapel, to a shop belong
ing to Mrs. Castle, and from there we went to Howe's, in Cambridge Heath Road, and took some metal from the other shop, and George Castle got out of the cart and had some talk with Howe, and then came and asked me to give him the wax, and it was taken into Howe's shop, and left there—it was white and yellow wax mixed, about, three-quarters of a cwt.—on one occasion we took wax there, George Castle said he would not leave it, because How he had not paid for the hut lot—it was brought back, and I think it was left with a man named Page—I have seen wax delivered at Howe's two or three times, about 3 or 4 cwt. on each occasion—I had also been in the cart with Castle to Jewell's shop, when wax was taken in a sack, yellow and white; that has happened several times, but I had never been in the shop.

Cross-examined by MR. W. SLEIGH. I have had no money from the police, but Sergeant Croome has sent me 5s. twice for my trouble in coming to the Court, and I have had; 10s. from Brockweli, not more—I have not had 2l. from him—he has not been paying all the witnesses—I have got into employment since this case began, with Mr. Purchas, of Wood Street, Golden Square—I got that for myself—I did not get a character; we don't require one in our line—I have been convicted of buying a ticket of a watch of a man who is doing seven years, but of nothing else—I got nine months—the police asked me to give them information as to who was buying this property, and I mentioned Ralph, and Castle, and Jewell—I did not mention King—I did not know that wax had been bought in large quantities by King, Edwards, Johnson, and others—I told the police that How was a receiver on the same night I spoke about Castle—I know Noble & Ross now—I never worked there in my life—I did not know from. Castle that Johnson and King bought largely—I saw Ralph at Castle's three times—I have no recollection of having said "I cannot swear whether or not I have seen Ralph at Mrs. Castle's three times"—I will not swear I did not—I said he had brought wax under his coat in a handkerchief—I cannot tell you the date—I did not; think it extraordinary—I mentioned, that before I heard of the reward—I have sworn that I should not mind receiving the reward of 20l., and that I did not say anything about it before I heard of the reward—I was then asked if I had told the police about it—It did not say I would not have the reward if it was offered me—I should like to have it now—I did not tell the Magistrate that I did not know the name of my employer—Mr. Lewis asked me to spell it; I could not do so till I looked at the paper—the name is Mitchener—I offered as an excuse that I had only been there a few days, and that I had a bad memory—I won't swear I did not say "I refused what was offered me"—I don't remember refusing anything—I came forward to assist the ends of justice—the matter about the ticket of a watch was eight or ten years ago—it was in Oakley Street, Lambeth—I am sure it was six or seven years ago—I was tried at the Surrey Sessions for receiving a stolen watch, the property of Mr. Moore, for whose father I. worked—I was never charged with stabbing my father
four weeks ago, or my brother; there is no truth in it—two policemen did not come to my house to look after me and take me, nor did I run away without my coat—there is no truth in the suggestion.
Cross-examined by MR. CROOM. I went into Mrs. Castle's service nine or ten years ago, but I had never been regularly in her service.
Ralph, I have never been in Mrs. Castle's shop. Witness, I am certain of you—I was shown a number of men and picked you out.

Re-examined. Mrs. Castle knew I was convicted—I was working for her at the time, and I went back there to work, and stayed there off and on for some years—she did not reproach me with my character then.

ELIZABETH DENNIS . I am the wife of Walter Dennis, of 44, Carlisle Street, Lambeth—I know Ralph by sight; he lives in the same Court opposite me, and Mrs. Scott lives in the same house with him—I have worked for Mrs. Castle several years at rag and paper sorting and house cleaning—I have seen Mrs. Scott come there from the end of September, or the beginning of October, till three weeks afterwards—she generally came every morning at 9 or 10 o'clock, and brought a large bundle under her shawl and went away without it—Mrs. Castle has been in the house at the time, and sometimes her son and son's wife—after Mrs. Scott left I have seen white and yellow wax on the floor, in the shape of basins—I saw that every time she came—when she came in I used to go out in the yard to do my work, and sometimes I was Bent for to get change, which I brought and gave to Mrs. Castle—I did net see what she did with it—my mother, Mrs. Cook, sometimes went there to work—our court is not five minutes' walk from Mr. Field's factory—Mrs. Castle sometimes told me to fetch her son while Mrs. Scott was there, and he came—I have seen Ralph, and Mrs. Scott, and George Castle, several times drinking together at the Carlisle Arms, which is not far from the factory—I went there to fetch beer—I saw Jewell there once with George Castle and Ralph—on 14th December George Castle told me to go to Jewell's house, and I went there and assisted them, and saw Ralph drive up to Jewell's door in a cart, which I believe was George Castle's—they brought something in a bag to Jewell's shop, and after they had gone I saw some large pieces of white wax in the parlour—once when I was working at Mrs. Castle's, George Castle gave me a bag, and asked me if I would take it to Jewell's for him—on my way I fell down—I then went into my own house and sat down, and the top of the bag came open, and I saw pieces of yellow wax in it—my sister-in
law and my mother were there, and saw it—that was in November—I took it to Jewell's, and saw Mrs. Jewell; Mr. Jewell was not up—shortly after dinner, in consequence of something my mother' said, I went to Mrs. Castle's, and told George Castle that a gentleman had been to my mother, and asked her if she was aware that Mrs. Castle bought, white wax and scented soap—he said "I have heard a different thing altogether"—Mrs. Castle came in and said "Liz, what is that?"—I asked her whether she was aware that the gentleman came and asked that—she said it was no such thing; that Castle used to try, but they did not now—I did not see the gentleman—I said it was nothing to do with me, but they must take warning—I went home and told my mother to come—I left off going' to Castle's on the Saturday after I left—I still saw Mrs. Scott going out of the house every morning with a bundle under her arm, not going towards Mrs. Castle's, but in a direction that would lead her to Jewell's, which is a quarter of an hour's walk—when she returned she had no bundle—Mrs. Castle's is ten minutes'

walk from my place—before Mrs. Castle was taken, in consequence of some
thing that was said to me, I went to Cookson's house; my mother and my husband went with me—when I got there I saw Mrs. Castle and her daughter—she said "Oh, Liz! you have done for me, nobody has been taken till to-night; Rumble has rounded"—I said I had seen the wax there, and told her what I had said to Mr. Field—she said "Oh, Liz! you have done for me and my boy; all you have said to-night you can deny in the morning; take care what you say for my son George and me"—Sergeant Croome then came in and took her in custody.

Cross-examined by MR. M. WILLIAMS. I have been told that if I gave evidence I should be well paid for it—this was just after I had told about the wax—I think it was Sergeant Croome who said so—I have been convicted twice, once for striking a person with a poker, and once for receiving a stolen jacket—I got one month for that—after that I had six months' for taking lodgings in a false name—it was not for robbing my lodgings, they were un
furnished—that was at Stone's End, Borough, and I think it was last July three years—my landlord prosecuted me, and I served the four months—I have received 5s. from Mr. Brockwell, and 2s. 6d. was given to my husband—I have not had 2l., nor have my family—Mrs. Cook is my mother—I have had 10s. a week, but not from Mr. Brockwell; it was given me by a gentleman at Mr. Field's; Croome has given me nothing—he gave my husband 2s. 6d. when Mrs. Castle was taken.

Cross-examined by MR. CROOME. I worked some time for Mrs. Castle; some
times in the yard and sometimes in the house—I took particular notice of Mrs. Scott, because people in the neighbourhood used to talk about her taking bundles out—I did not take notice of any other customer, because no other customer used to come into the parlour—I used to do the house cleaning, and when she came I was always in the parlour—I was there from 8 in the morning till 7 at night—I saw her there on the Monday or Tuesday in the week I left, but not in the latter part of the week—I. was first asked about this the end of April, after I left—I had not talked it over in the meanwhile, and my attention bad not been drawn to it—I don't know that Mrs. Scott brought a number of bags for Mrs. Castle in the bundle, as she finished them.

Cross-examined by MR. LYON. I don't know that Mrs. Scott took in washing—I have not seen babies' petticoats hanging outside Mrs. Castle's door—Mrs. Scott used to take a bundle under one arm, and a basket on the other to Mrs. Castle's—I have known her three or four years, but never knew her to take in washing—she did wash for my mother three years ago, but not lately—I don't know that she washed for Mrs. Bitham, of the Carlisle Arms, for four year.
Re-examined. Mrs. Castle knew I had been convicted, and used to send for me afterwards—I had to go several times to the Police Court, and lost my work, and have had none since.

JOHN CROOME . I am a detective-serjeant of Scotlaud Yard—I was first instructed in April—I accompanied Mr. Field on his first visit to King's, and from there we went to Jewell's, where I heard a conversation between Mr. Field and Jewell—after leaving Jewell's we went to Castle's and had some conversation with George Castle—Mr. Field gave him the opportunity to find out the person he spoke of, and he promised to come and see Mr. Field on the 15th April—I never saw him again till I took him in custody at Paddington on 3rd June—I told him in the passage that I had been

walk from my place—before Mrs. Castle was taken, in consequence of some
thing that was said to me, I went to Cookson's house; my mother and my husband went with me—when I got there I saw Mrs. Castle and her daughter—she said "Oh, Liz I you have done for me, nobody has been taken till to-night; Rumble has rounded"—I said I had seen the wax there, and told her what I had said to Mr. Field—she said "Oh, Liz I you have done for me and my boy; all you have said to-night you can deny in the morning; take care what you say for my son George and me"—Sergeaut Croome then came in and took her in custody.

Cross-examined by MR. M. WILLIAMS. I have been told that if I gave evidence I should be well paid for it—this was just after I had told about the wax—I think it was Sergeant Croome who said so—I have been convicted twice, once for striking a person with a poker, and once for receiving a stolen jacket—I got one month for that—after that I had six months' for taking lodgings in a false name—it was not for robbing my lodgings, they were un
furnished—that was at Stone's End, Borough, and I think it was last July three years—my landlord prosecuted me, and I served the four months—I have received 5s. from Mr. Brockwell, and 2s. 6d. was given to my husband—I have not had 2l., nor have my family—Mrs. Cook is my mother—I have had 10s. a week, but not from Mr. Brockwell; it was given me by a gentleman at Mr. Field's; Croome has given me nothing—he gave my husband 2s. 6d. when Mrs. Castle was taken.

Cross-examined by MR. CROOME. I worked some time for Mrs. Castle; some
times in the yard and sometimes in the house—I took particular notice of Mrs. Scott, because people in the neighbourhood used to talk about her taking bundles out—I did not take notice of any other customer, because no other customer used to Come into the parlour—I used to do the house cleaning, and when she came I was always in the parlour—I was there from 8 in the morning till 7 at night—I saw her there on the Monday or Tuesday in the week I left, but not in the latter part of the week—I was first asked about this the end of April, after I left—I had not talked it over in—the meanwhile, and my attention had not been drawn to it—I don't know that Mrs. Scott brought a number of bags for Mrs. Castle in the bundle, as she finished them.

Cross-examined by MR. LYON. I don't know that Mrs. Scott took in washing—I have not seen babies' petticoats hanging outside Mrs. Castle's door—Mrs. Scott used to take a bundle under one arm, and a basket on the other to Mrs. Castle's—I have known her three or four years, but never knew her to take in washing—she did wash for my mother three years ago, but not lately—I don't know that she washed for Mrs. Bitham, of the Carlisle Arms, for four years.
Re-examined. Mrs. Castle knew I had been convicted, and used to send for me afterwards—I had to go several times to the Police Court, and lost,. my work, and have had none since.

JOHN CROOME . I am a detective-serjeant of Scotlaud Yard—I was first instructed in April—I accompanied Mr. Field on his first visit to King's, and from there we went to Jewell's, where I heard a conversation between Mr. Field and Jewell—after leaving Jewell's we went to Castle's and had some conversation with George Castle—Mr. Field gave him the opportunity to find out the person he spoke of, and he promised to come and see Mr. Field on the 15th April—I never saw him again till I took him in custody at Paddington on 3rd June—I told him in the passage that I had been

looking for him some time and should take him in custody—he said "Well, don't make a noise, there are people here"—we went into the parlour, and the females went out—I told him the charge and he said "Have you got Jewell"—I said "No, not yet"—he said "He knows as much about it as I do"—I took him to the station—I had been to his mother's shop for him, and also to the house where he lived, but could not find him—on 30th April I took Mrs. Castle at her son's house—Mrs. Dennis was present, and Mrs. Cook, and Mrs. Dennis's husband, the son-in-law—I told her the charge—she said "I know nothing about it"—I said that Mrs. Scott had been seen on several occasions going to her house with a bag—she said she did not know Mrs. Scott, and asked me to let her stay till the morning—I said No, I had already been to her house, and was told she was out—I took her to the station—on 24th April I went to Howe's premises, under instruc
tions from Mr. Field, and purchased of Howe 10 lbs. of wax, 7 lbs of which was afterwards identified—I said I wanted half a cwt. or more—he said he could not supply me then, but no doubt he could get it—I paid him 10s. 8d. for the 10 lbs., but it was weighed as only 7 lbs.—I called again on the 28th, I told him he had made a mistake, and charged only 7 lbs.—instead of 10 lbs., and gave him 5s. more, making 16s. 8d.—he had told me on the first occasion that he could not tell of whom he bought the wax, and he took down a file and searched, and produced a printed bill with the heading torn off, and said "This is the receipt," but I found it referred to oil—on the second occasion, 30th April, he produced a bill with the name of Hayward on it, but no address, and told me he had asked for the man's address, but he would not give it him—I asked him if he knew a man named Castle—he said "No"—we both asked him if he had given samples to a man named Addis, in the employ of Mr. Williams, 108, Minories, to sell 2 cwt. of wax—he said "No, I don't know the man, and have never given samples of wax to anyone to sell"—I took Howe in cus
tody on 8th May at his house, and told him it was for receiving some wax—he said "I did not receive it, I bought it of the man I told you, Hayward, a traveller"—I took Ralph on 30th April, and told him the charge was stealing large quantities of Mr. Field's wax—he said "1 know nothing about it, very well, I will go"—on the night of June 6th, I took Witham at a public-house in Suffolk Street, Mile End, and told him the charge—he said "I did not receive it, what I have shown and tried to sell to Mr. Steer of Lambeth Walk, and Mr. Hall of the Cut, and another person, was given me to sell by George Castle"—he did not mention the third name, but he described the shop in Union Street, Borough, and said "If you lock me up I shall tell the Magistrate all I know; I don't see why I should suffer for other people; I hope Mr. Field will not discharge a number of innocent men, as there are only two or three more in it.

Cross-examined by MR. WARNER SLEIGH. I gave Howe no intimation on the first occasion that I was a detective; he did not know it till the second occasion—I did not find out the mistake in the charge for the wax till I went home—it was got out by Mrs. Howe, and when I said that I wanted some more, she fetched her husband from the parlour—I gave a sovereign, I think, and the change was given me in silver—if Howe had been candid, and told me where he bought it, Mr. Field would not have charged him—he said on the first occasion that he would get a receipt for the wax from the traveller who came every Thursday, and on the second occasion he voluntarily produced the receipt—I have never given Mrs. Dennis anything

she was putting her boots on—she then took the wax away, and re
turned without it—soon after Christmas a man come and asked me if I was aware that Mrs. Castle bought white or yellow wax, or scented soap—I said "No," and told my daughter, who was working at Castle's at the time—she went there next day and returned, and in consequence of what she said I went there and saw George Castle and his mother—I said the gentleman asked me if I was aware whether they bought white or yellow wax, or scented soap, and that I had said "No"—she said "I will tell you what Mrs. Scott brought; it was a few candles, and a little soap, and I could as well send you to Mr. Field's for it as her"—young Mrs. Castle said that they had a different story to that, for someone passed and heard the conversation, and it was said some one used to buy it who did not buy it now—I told my daughter's hus
band of this, and she left in consequence at the end of the week—I was present when Mrs. Castle was apprehended at her son-in-law, Cook
son's house—she said to my daughter, "Liz, if you have said anything, you have done for me and my boy, but never mind, you can deny all you said to-morrow morning"—my daughter had told her that she had been to Mr. Field's—the police then came, and nothing more was said.

Cross-examined by MR. LYON. Mrs. Scott went out sometimes at 10 o'clock, and sometimes a little after—I only went out to work once or twice a week, sometimes at 8 o'clock, sometimes at 10 o'clock, and sometimes at 2 o'clock, just as people wanted me—I only saw Mrs. Scott at Castle's twice, both times on Saturdays—Mrs. Scott has never done anything for me, nor" do I know that she took in washing, but she did a little for me, at her own house, two years ago, when I took in washing—I have not seen her go out with a basket—I do not know that she made babies' frocks and petticoats—I never saw any outside her door—I never bought one of her—what I said at the Police Court was that I bought one of Mrs. Castle—when Mrs. Castle was taken, I did not say "Thank God! I know nothing about it," or "Thank God, they cannot touch me."

Cross-examined by MR. LEWIS. Mrs. Cookson has three babies—one of them was not dying at that time—my daughter has only been convicted twice, not three times—I did not say "Mrs. Cookson, this is your doing, and now I will make it hot for your mother."

Re-examined. My daughter was employed at Mrs. Castle's at the time she was convicted, and she worked for her afterwards—I did not know that Mrs. Scott was a laundress, or that she washed for the Carlisle public-house.

ELIZABETH DENNIS . I am the sister-in-law of the other Elizabeth Dennis—I was at Mrs. Cookson's house when Mrs. Dennis came in—she had a little white bag with her—I looked at it, and saw three pieces of yellow wax, in the shape of a basin—she said she was going to take it to Jewell's.

MARY ANN FRANCES . I am the wife of Alfred Frances, of 48, Union Street, thirteen doors from Mrs. Castle's, in the same street—Mrs. Scott came into my shop last August—as a rule she generally carried something under her shawl, in this way—I may take an oath that I have seen her do so four times a week—she generally bought something when she came, and she generally told me she was going to Mrs. Castle's, and would call for it as she came back—she was away sometimes half an hour, or it might be an hour—sometimes she paid beforehand, but generally afterwards—she never had any bundle under her shawl when she came back—on the Saturday

after Christmas she came in with Ralph and another man, who I do not know, and Scott said to Ralph "Come along, let us be going now;" and she said that they wanted to see Maggie—that is George Castle's wife—she said that she would call as she came back—she did not do so, but the other man came, not Ralph—she had told me previously that Maggie had been barmaid at the Carlisle Arms—that is near Mr. Field's factory—she came in on the day of the University Boat Race, and bought a small tin sauce
pan and a small vase, and left them till she came back—when she came back she had something under her shawl—she generally came four times a week, an I generally bought something: shirts, chemises, drawers, and articles of all descriptions—I did not notice on what days she came—I have sworn to four days positively, but she was in the habit of coming in regularly every day—I was quite as positive at the Police Court as I am now—she carried a bundle after Christmas, the same as before—at times she bought nothing, but only came in to have a little conversation—when she made a purchase she made a bundle, and carried it on top of a small bag or basket—I did not say at the Police Court that the things she bought of me she sometimes put under her shawl—my deposition was read over to me, and I signed it—I do not believe I ever said it—I have been in the habit of dealing with the prosecutor's firm—I first spoke to the man I take the paper from about giving evidence—before that I had no idea whatever of giving evidence.

Cross-examined. I did not buy soap and candles of the prosecutor, only waste-paper—when Mrs. Castle has come to my place I have seen some thing under her shawl, but I have not known what it was—George Castle's house is thirteen houses distant from my shop—I did not know that she was a laundry-woman—I should have put things under my shawl as she did, I have no doubt.

MARY SIMONS . I know the Castles—I went to their house last year, but not to buy anything—I saw a cart standing outside, and things were being put into it—the horse's head was towards Lambeth Walk—Mrs. Castle was inside the shop, and her son, too—I saw some parcels on the counter, and an ordinary carpet bag, such as a gentleman might travel with—one parcel that was in the bag fell over, and I saw that it contained white wax, some of it escaped on to the counter—this was more than a year ago.

CHARLES SIMONS . I know the Castles—about three months ago I met George Castle in a horse and cart, he stopped under the tail of the cart, and took out two large cakes of white wax and one of brown—they were in the shape of a bowl—he took them into his shop.

SEYMOUR SUNDELL . I am a glass shade and wax flower maker, at 51, Lower Marsh—I have known the woman Scott—about three months ago I bought some wooden cases of her; I noticed a little wax about the mouths of the cases—she afterwards came and asked if I was disposed to buy wax—she brought about 10 lbs. as a sample, she said they mixed it themselves—and so they could sell it cheaper than anyone else—it was white wax—she asked me 18d. a lb.—from, first to last I bought about 80 lbs. of her at 1s. 40d.—I ultimately sold about 22 lbs, of it to Mr. Soames, the traveller to Mr. Field, the remainder was used for my home purposes.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. My workman made it into wax flowers—I got 2s. per lb. from Mr. Soames—I did not know of the robbery at that time—Mr. Field came to me about it—Mrs. Scott told me that her husband was a wax mixer—I went to her house about the wood I bought—I saw no

sign of wax mixing there—I never saw her husband—the wood was in a shed at the side of the house; it is a cottage—I got no receipt for the wax—I did not have it in one lot, but in seven or eight, as I wanted it—I did not enter it in my book.

THOMAS SEXTON . I am a furniture dealer, of 16; Great Charlotte Street, Blackfriars Road—I know Jewell and George Castle—on one occasion I saw them together outside my shop—they had a horse and cart—Jewell showed me a piece of yellow wax, and I believe there was some white in the parcel—I went with them in the cart to several places for the purpose of selling it—there was about half or three-quarters of a cwt. in the cart, both yellow and white—we did not find a customer—I had known Jewell six or seven years—I had never known him dealing in wax before.
Cross-examined by MR. LEWIS. The wax that I saw in the cart was exceedingly dirty.

JAMES BE VAN . I am a chairmaker, of 12, Great Charlotte Street, Blackfriars Road—in consequence of what Sexton said to me, I went out and found a cart, and George Castle with it—at the bottom of the cart there was a large quantity of yellow and white wax of different shapes; some were basin-shaped, and some in thin pieces, some entire and some broken—Sexton asked me, in George Castle's presence, if I would buy it—I use wax in my trade—I understood they wanted about 1s. a lb. for it—I think the lump price was to be 3l. 10s. for all that was in the cart—I said I did not want any myself, but I went round with them to about twelve other chair makers—I 5d. a lb. was asked—we could not find a customer—we then went to George Castle's premises, in Union Street, and from there to Jewell's, in Gibson Street—Jewell asked George Castle "How do you get on?"—they spoke on one side—I could not hear what they said after that—we then went in the cart to Sexton's place 0—I said to Jewell, in George Castle's presenoe, "Have you been opposite?" that was to Bawn's, the chairmaker's—he said "Yes"—I asked if he had been to Edwards's, the doll-makers—George Castle said he had been there a long while ago—I said, if I had a customer at a future time would he have any more—he said "Plenty"—I have known Jewell two or three years as a neighbour, but not to speak to him—I had never known him dealing in wax.

Cross-examined by MR. LEWIS. Some of the wax was very dirty—I said I did not care about having anything to do with it for my own business—some of it was in small pieces, and some larger—it had the appearance of old wax—I was not to get any benefit out of it—I went with them as much for a ride as anything else—perhaps I might have had something if it had been sold, but I was not offered anything.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. The Castles were not known to me—Mr. Sexton asked me about it—travellers come round with wax and all sorts of things to sell—we deal at a certain place, and have done for years.

WILLIAM JAMES BOOTH . I am eleven years old—I life at 3, College Place—Mrs. Scott lives in the same court—she gave my mother a cat—just after Christmas I went to Mrs. Scott's garden to look for it—I found it under the straw in a shed—I saw some wooden boxes there covered over with straw, and on the ground I saw three pieces of white wax—I dropped one of them, it was a three cornered piece—it broke into three little pieces—I took it home to my grandmother—I saw Mrs. Scott go out at 8 o'clock one morning, with a parcel under her shawl.
Cross-examined by MR. LYON. I found my cat in the shed under the straw,
playing with the kitten—I did not not lift up much of the straw—the wax was rather dirty.

GEORGE MAY . I am a chair-maker—I know Mrs. Castle; not much of her son—about ten months ago she came to my shop—I was not at home, I saw her afterwards—she left some wax, about 12 lbs.—it was of a reddish cast—she asked me 2s. 1lb. for it—I did not take it because I can buy it 1s. 4d. a lb. or 2 oz. at a time for that.
Cross-examined by MR. LEWIS. I thought she asked too much, and I do not use above a quarter of a pound a week, and that would have lasted me a twelvemonth.

HENRY ADDIS . I am in the employ of Williams & Co., 108, Minories—the prisoner Howe has been known to me some little time; he has an oil and colour man's business in Cambridge Heath Road—I have been in the habit of using the Three Colts public-house, a short distance from his house—I had a conversation with his brother about some wax, and afterwards with him—he handed me two pieces of wax, one dark and one light—he said he should have about 2 cwt. of it; this was given me as a sample—he said he wanted a quarter of a pound—I showed the sample to Palmer, and also to Mr. Williams, my employer—I afterwards saw Howe, and told him they would buy half a cwt. at Mr. Williams's, and a cwt. at Mr. Gadsden's.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. I have been in Mr. Williams's employ two and a half years—I was in respectable employment before then—I have known Howe some years; he has borne an excellent character during that time—I have not been paid 1l. a day for my expenses; I had 1l. the first day, and a half-crown for a cab home—it was Howe's brother that showed me the samples, not Howe himself—I said at first that it was Howe; but, on considering, I found it was his brother—he gave me the samples in his presence—he went and fetched them from his premises; they are the same premises as the prisoner's—he is a wholesale, as well as a retail, oil and colourman—he keeps a man on the premises to mix wax—after I saw Mr. Field about this, I told Howe that I had heard the wax was stolen, and he had better not have anything to do with it—he said he should not buy any mure of it, and he was much obliged to me for telling him of it.

Re-examined. The shop is Howe's, I believe—the brother fetched the samples from the shop, and brought them to me at the public-house and asked if I could-sell them—I said "Yes"—both the brothers were at the public-house—I saw them afterwards several times, both in the shop toge
ther—the prisoner sometimes took part in the conversation—this was about Whitsuntide, I think; about the middle of April.

EDWIN MIDDLETON . I am with my brother, an oil and colourman, in George Street, St. George's-in—the East—I have known Howe personally about twelve months—I have done business with him about two years—in August last year I bought 104 lbs. of wax of him at 1s. a lb., with some oil and cans—this is the invoice—the amount is 23l. 3s. 6d.—on one occa
sion I went to his premises in Cambridge Heath Road, to the back of the shop, and there saw some pieces of yellow wax—there was also a transaction in April, 1 cwt. 2 qrs. 6 lbs., at 1s. 3d. a lb.—a portion of the wax I bought of Howe was afterwards shown to Mr. Field and his foreman.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. I have known Howe for two years as a respectable tradesman—I have never heard a blemish on his character—some part of the wax we should not have paid so much for, as it was not

genuine wax—sometimes we buy from samples of travellers who come round—Howe give us these receipts at the time—everything was done in a per
fectly business-like manner.
(Re-examined) When travellers come round they give the names and addresses of their principals.

EDWIN WALKER . I am manager to Messrs. Field, at the Star Night Light Works—I have known Witham in the neighbourhood of those works for some years—after the apprehension of Ralph and Mrs. Castle, I met Witham in Union Street—he said "What do you want with me?"—I said I thought he could give some information relative to the robbery of the wax from Mr. Field's—he said "Yes, I can, I know all about it; I bought three-quarters of a cwt. some odd pounds in Castle's shop myself'—I asked him if he would come and tell Mr. Field—he said "No, I do not want to see Mr. Field, but I shall be at the Court next hearing, and I will tell the Magistrate the same as I have told you"—next evening I met him at the same place, and I then told him that I found he had offered wax for sale—he at first said "I—No"—I said "It is no use for you to deny it, because I can tell you to whom you offered it"—he asked me who—I said to Mr. Hall's assistant, and also to Mr. Steane"—he said "Well, yes, I did," and he said he would tell that to the Magistrate—I again asked him if he would go to Mr. Field—he said No, ho would be at the Court next day, and he would tell the Magistrate the same as he told mo—I saw nothing more of him till Whit-Tuesday, when he came to me at the works in Paradise Street—he asked if I wanted to see him—I said "No, but if you have anything to say to me, I am quite ready to hear it"—he asked if I was not going to treat him—I said "Yes, you may have what you like"—we went together to the Bell public-house in Church Street, and he had half a quartern of gin—I left the house for a few minutes, and when I came back he had gone to the Crown—I called him out; he was not perfectly sober; and in a rambling manner he said he would tell Mr. Field that the man whom he discharged knew nothing about the robbery; that the right man was locked up, and two other men were at liberty—I then took him to Mr. Field, and after a conversion with him, I followed him out—he stopped and told me he could not say anything unless I locked him up; situated as he was he could not say a word out there, because if he did, he should never get another day's work among this class of people.

Cross-examined by MR. LYON. I mentioned that at the Police Court—a lad named William Maunder, a nephew of mine, first brought him to me—I sent him for him—when I first saw him in Union Street he went into the Dolphin public-house with one of the Castles—I did not give him any money on that occasion—I lent him a shilling the night I took him to Mr. Field—he said he had no money, and asked if I would give him a shilling—I said "No"—he said "Lend me a shilling"—I said "I will lend you one if you like, but I shall never get it again, I suppose"—that was understood I think.

EDWARD DAVIS . I am warehouseman to Mr. Hall, an oilman in Lambeth Road—I know Witham—about twelve months ago he came and offered me some wax for sale—he said he had about three-quarters of a cwt.—he left me a sample—I showed it to my employer, but none was bought—it was yellow wax—I have since seen the sample that he brought me.
Cross-examined by MR. LYON He did not say who he was selling it for
—he said he was selling it for a party; he did not mention the name—I knew he was acquainted with the Castles.

FREDERICK GEORGE STEANE . I am an oil and colourman, 170, Lambeth Walk—in September last young Witham came and offered me some yellow wax for sale—he brought a sample first, and then a bag, about three-quarters of a cwt.—he asked 1s. per lb. for it—he said he had bought it at a rummage sale of the South Western Railway—I asked him to show me a catalogue of the sale—he did not do so—I would not buy it, and he took it away.
Cross-examined by MR. LYON. It was what was known in the trade as Jamaica beeswax; it was not all yellow, but light and dark—the market value at that time was about eight guineas a cwt.

WILLIAM PEACOCK (Police Inspector L) I was on duty at Tower Street station on the morning of 7th June—at that time Witham was in custody in one of the cells—T visited him during the night and morning, and asked if he was all right—he said "Yes," and he wanted to make a statement to me about the matter he was in the cell for, and requested that it might be detailed to the Magistrate—he said "I know all about it; I had some of the wax given to me to sell; I offered it for sale to a foreman of Mr. Hall's, Lambeth Road; they refused to purchase it. I left a sample; that was returned to me. I was employed by Mr. George Castle, of Union Street, Lambeth Walk; in June last a man drove up in Union Street, with a horse and cart, in front of a paper shop, near Castle's house, with three lots of wax. I weighed one of them; it weighed three-quarters of a cwt I don't remember what the others weighed. Mr. Castle was present at the time.

SOLOMON DALES (Policeman L 34), At 10 o'clock on the night of 1st May, I took Harriett Scott into custody—I told her she would be charged with others in stealing wax from Messrs. Field's, and that Ralph was at the station—she said Ralph was a lodger of hers; if he knew anything about the wax she did not.

WILLIAM RUMBLE (re-examined). I have sworn that I was not taken to the Police Court by two policemen; that was what I said, and that was what I meant—I was taken by one man—I was not charged at all; no charge was made; I was taken to the station and let go—I was summoned by a man named Enowles for an assault—it was all put on to me by the Castles—no charge was entered on the sheet; I can swear that.

p.hi: Howe and the two Castles received good characters.

div1.p:
RALPH—
GUILTY of stealing.

SCOTT, M. A. CASTLE, HOWE, GEORGE CASTLE, and WITHAM—
GUILTY
of receiving. Judgment Respited.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 22ND, 1873.
